description: Are we, or are we not, at war with a hidden enemy? If we are, then the Quislings are cheerleaders for anything anti-American and inadvertently collude with foreign entities such as the Chinese Communist government, Russia and all other regimes wishing for our democratic way of life to fail. The negativity on the part of propagandizing false truths at the U.S....
text:
Are we, or are we not, at war with a hidden enemy (the Wuhan virus)? If we are
not, the Quisling politicians, newspaper outlets, alphabet TV stations, et
al., are correct.

If we are, then the Quislings are cheerleaders for anything anti-American and
inadvertently collude with foreign entities such as the Chinese Communist
government, Russia and all other regimes wishing for our democratic way of
life to fail.

To be objective and watch a variety of news broadcasts is disheartening. The
negativity on the part of propagandizing false truths at the U.S. government
and the president during wartime is tantamount to the destruction of our
democratic way of life. Criticism with substantive facts (not regurgitation of
so-called news personalities, et al.) should be acceptable with doubt.

Where has this negativity originated?

In a war when people use derogatory terms and regurgitate someone else's
thoughts other than theirs, it becomes biased, and a skewed view that our
adversaries are masters at. When an undermining of a democratic process of
facts without due process of rights, it corrupts and destroys.

"No one is above the law," it's said, but in my opinion it should have
continued "unless you are  ."

Several attempts have been directed against American citizens by politicized
agencies such as IRS, FBI, CIA, NSA; the Justice Department and the FISA
court; and congressional committees. This is frightening. The expenditure of
millions upon millions of of taxpayer dollars by these parties (no one has
accounted for each probe) with the express idea of "Gotcha!" has made lawyers
wealthy, taxpayers poorer and our enemies emboldened because they successfully
sowed the seeds of destruction of our country from within.

Remember, if this is a war, the outcome is either winning or losing.

Ed Winslow, Port St. Lucie

One of the more surprising responses to the global COVID-19 pandemic has been
Rep. Brian Mast's display (online column, May 7) of a deep-seated disdain for
the men and women of Florida agriculture.

Instead of meeting their dedication to sustainably growing and harvesting food
in the middle of a food shortage with appreciation, he has doubled down by
attacking them through the media and even threatening to take their water.

What did farmers south of Lake Okeechobee do to so anger Rep. Mast? Was it
their decades of perfecting the growth of food crops people want and need.
along with cleaner water? Or their commitment to growing a diversity of food
including fresh fruit such as bananas and mangos, vegetables such as lettuce,
green beans and sweet corn as well as organic rice?

Because when he attacks "Big Sugar," he also attacks all the farmers that grow
sugarcane along with these crops that are grown in rotation with cane.

Fortunately, our local farmers didn't close when government shut down non-
essential businesses. That is why Mast's anti-farming rhetoric is so
surprising. He should do better, for everyone's sake.

Lisa Walker, Clewiston

In recognition of Foster Parent Appreciation Month, I want to thank our local
caregivers who - even during a pandemic - welcome hurting children into their
lives. The children we place into their homes are among the most vulnerable
citizens in our community. They are the abused, the neglected; some of them
have been abandoned - all by people they trusted.

COVID-19 and the possibility that foster parents might shut their homes in
fear of contagion made these children all the more vulnerable. But our
caregivers did not shut their doors.

Every year, every day, foster parents take sick children without hesitation.
They take them with the flu, with coughs and colds. They take them with mental
and behavioral issues that pose health risks of their own. Foster parents open
their homes to these children because something calls them to do so. They hear
the call to act and run headfirst into the unknown. The pandemic changed none
of this.

The caregiver call to action has never been more important. Calls to the
state's abuse registry have decreased significantly during the shutdown -
something we expected when schools closed and teachers could no longer see
their students every day. We know that isolation and stress lead to abuse, and
so we are preparing for more children to enter care once the pandemic has
ended and our community is fully reopened.

Our existing foster parents are doing the best they can during this trying
time, but children continue to come into care and need homes. If you have
thought about being a foster parent but concerns about COVID-19 have kept you
from moving forward, we ask you to reconsider. We are sending out the call; we
are asking for your help.

Carol Deloach, Port St. Lucie

Carol Deloach is the chief executive officer of Communities Connected for Kids
in Port St. Lucie.

With the county getting back to normal, I am sure county and local budgets
will be needy. EMS and others really had a lot of overtime, no doubt way above
what was budgeted.

A quick look at where we can save money seems to be dumping sand in the ocean.
The county has spent hundreds of thousands on sand. Let's think smart about
this.

There is construction going on around the county. Mapp Road and Southeast
Commerce Avenue both have construction projects going on. Why not take all
that old concrete they are digging up for an artificial reef?

The county should set aside an easy-to-reach lot of land for citizens to bring
concrete pieces. Once you get a big pile of concrete pieces, put them on a
barge and just a little offshore, dump the pieces in a line. In no time nature
will use this and coral will grow and lobsters will live in the broken pipes.

Best of all it will protect our beaches, for many years to come, and save
money in the process.

John Spatuzzi, Palm City

Recently our country has witnessed a rupture between those who feel that their
individual freedom is being violated by local or state orders to stay at home
and close businesses, and those who feel that these restrictions, no matter
how personally onerous they may be, are necessary for the common good and
safety.

Thus we read of armed vigilantes carrying AR-15 semiautomatic rifles
surrounding a tattoo parlor in Odessa, Texas, to protect an owner who is
defying state orders. We all have seen similarly armed vigilantes storming the
state capitol in Lansing, Michigan, to try to intimidate the state governor to
make her comply with their interpretation of their constitutional right to go
anywhere they want whenever they want.

They are mistaken about their constitutional rights, particularly in an
emergency like this pandemic. Nor do they have the right to arm themselves to
deliberately intimidate their fellow citizens or their duly-elected officials
trying to protect the general public. These are the acts of thugs who
represent a minority view but think they can threaten their fellow citizens
with guns to get their way.

In a recent letter I read, "Closing beaches here in Florida is like outlawing
prayer in church. Not acceptable under any circumstances." Here we have the
same total misunderstanding of our individual rights (plus a horrible
analogy!). As a retired history teacher, I get depressed reading these
comments, about these vigilante actions and wonder what we teachers have
failed to do to educate our citizens.

The three examples I mention all indicate a serious problem many Americans
have in putting their personal desires over the common good, wishful thinking
over science, and opinion over facts. It's time to grow up!

Andrew Sorbo, Sebastian

Now that Gov. Ron DeSantis has lifted the prohibition on elective medical
procedures in Florida, it is important for individuals who have been putting
off important tests and treatments to see their physicians for the care they
need.

While the prohibition was necessary to ensure Florida's healthcare system was
capable of handling the COVID-19 crisis, an unintended consequence was that
many people with conditions ranging from abdominal pain to trauma stayed home
instead of getting the early treatment that could minimize damage and improve
patient outcomes.

To prevent a second healthcare crisis, people need to know that physician
practices have reopened in every part of the state with protocols in place to
ensure that patients are cared for safely.

The Florida Medical Association, along with the American Medical Association
and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, have provided guidelines
and checklists for physician practices to follow to ensure that patients are
protected to the greatest extent possible. Requiring patients to wear face
coverings, limiting non-patient visitors, and screening patients before in-
person visits are among the new protocols that have been put into place.
Testing of physicians and medical staff members has increased and enhanced
sanitization procedures have been implemented.

Physician practices are taking these extra precautions to encourage their
patients to continue obtaining in-person care when medical attention is needed
- especially those with preexisting conditions that require follow-up care
with a healthcare provider.

Patients who have chronic medical problems need to have regular check-ups to
make sure they are doing well. Postponing care because of the COVID-19 crisis
puts patients at high risk for complications later and eventually could cause
a treatable condition to become untreatable.

The resulting complications could end up being worse than the (COVID-19)
disease.

Ronald Giffler, Tallahassee

Ronald Giffler, M.D., J.D., M.B.A., is President of the Florida Medical
Association

Why do delivery people no longer knock when leaving a package at our
residences?

In the past they always knocked to alert us that we had a delivery. A good
system, I think. In the last few months we had numerous things delivered and
the driver did not knock. This includes UPS, Amazon and Walmart, among others.

I asked one driver why he didn't knock and he said it was because he had taken
a photo to show that the item arrived at the proper destination. I explained
that this in no way protected me from having the item stolen.

Some companies send constant updates as to where your shipment is and when it
is delivered at your door. That is all well and good, but is not a reason to
not knock on the door of the home when the package is dropped off. I don't sit
at my computer all day. Nor am I constantly using a smart phone.

On YouTube you can see a lot of videos of thieves stealing packages from door-
steps and porches. They are known as "Porch Pirates." The delivery companies
know this is happening. In a couple videos you can see the driver lay the
package down, take a photo, and then pick up the item and walk away with it.

Come on, delivery companies, you should and can do better. In the past, I
admired drivers because they were so thoughtful. Last week a driver left a
package, containing medication, in the sun when two feet away shade was
available all day. No, he didn't knock.

Jerry Brewer, Fort Pierce

title: Letters to the Editor: May 26, 2020
html:
Are we, or are we not, at war with a hidden enemy (the Wuhan virus)? If we are not, the Quisling politicians, newspaper outlets, alphabet TV stations, et al., are correct.

If we are, then the Quislings are cheerleaders for anything anti-American and inadvertently collude with foreign entities such as the Chinese Communist government, Russia and all other regimes wishing for our democratic way of life to fail.

To be objective and watch a variety of news broadcasts is disheartening. The negativity on the part of propagandizing false truths at the U.S. government and the president during wartime is tantamount to the destruction of our democratic way of life. Criticism with substantive facts (not regurgitation of so-called news personalities, et al.) should be acceptable with doubt.

Where has this negativity originated?

In a war when people use derogatory terms and regurgitate someone else's thoughts other than theirs, it becomes biased, and a skewed view that our adversaries are masters at. When an undermining of a democratic process of facts without due process of rights, it corrupts and destroys.

"No one is above the law," it's said, but in my opinion it should have continued "unless you are … ."

Several attempts have been directed against American citizens by politicized agencies such as IRS, FBI, CIA, NSA; the Justice Department and the FISA court; and congressional committees. This is frightening. The expenditure of millions upon millions of of taxpayer dollars by these parties (no one has accounted for each probe) with the express idea of "Gotcha!" has made lawyers wealthy, taxpayers poorer and our enemies emboldened because they successfully sowed the seeds of destruction of our country from within.

Remember, if this is a war, the outcome is either winning or losing.

Ed Winslow, Port St. Lucie

One of the more surprising responses to the global COVID-19 pandemic has been Rep. Brian Mast's display (online column, May 7) of a deep-seated disdain for the men and women of Florida agriculture.

Instead of meeting their dedication to sustainably growing and harvesting food in the middle of a food shortage with appreciation, he has doubled down by attacking them through the media and even threatening to take their water.

What did farmers south of Lake Okeechobee do to so anger Rep. Mast? Was it their decades of perfecting the growth of food crops people want and need. along with cleaner water? Or their commitment to growing a diversity of food including fresh fruit such as bananas and mangos, vegetables such as lettuce, green beans and sweet corn as well as organic rice?

Because when he attacks "Big Sugar," he also attacks all the farmers that grow sugarcane along with these crops that are grown in rotation with cane.

Fortunately, our local farmers didn't close when government shut down non-essential businesses. That is why Mast's anti-farming rhetoric is so surprising. He should do better, for everyone's sake.

Lisa Walker, Clewiston

In recognition of Foster Parent Appreciation Month, I want to thank our local caregivers who - even during a pandemic - welcome hurting children into their lives. The children we place into their homes are among the most vulnerable citizens in our community. They are the abused, the neglected; some of them have been abandoned - all by people they trusted.

COVID-19 and the possibility that foster parents might shut their homes in fear of contagion made these children all the more vulnerable. But our caregivers did not shut their doors.

Every year, every day, foster parents take sick children without hesitation. They take them with the flu, with coughs and colds. They take them with mental and behavioral issues that pose health risks of their own. Foster parents open their homes to these children because something calls them to do so. They hear the call to act and run headfirst into the unknown. The pandemic changed none of this.

The caregiver call to action has never been more important. Calls to the state's abuse registry have decreased significantly during the shutdown - something we expected when schools closed and teachers could no longer see their students every day. We know that isolation and stress lead to abuse, and so we are preparing for more children to enter care once the pandemic has ended and our community is fully reopened.

Our existing foster parents are doing the best they can during this trying time, but children continue to come into care and need homes. If you have thought about being a foster parent but concerns about COVID-19 have kept you from moving forward, we ask you to reconsider. We are sending out the call; we are asking for your help.

Carol Deloach, Port St. Lucie

Carol Deloach is the chief executive officer of Communities Connected for Kids in Port St. Lucie.

With the county getting back to normal, I am sure county and local budgets will be needy. EMS and others really had a lot of overtime, no doubt way above what was budgeted.

A quick look at where we can save money seems to be dumping sand in the ocean. The county has spent hundreds of thousands on sand. Let's think smart about this.

There is construction going on around the county. Mapp Road and Southeast Commerce Avenue both have construction projects going on. Why not take all that old concrete they are digging up for an artificial reef?

The county should set aside an easy-to-reach lot of land for citizens to bring concrete pieces. Once you get a big pile of concrete pieces, put them on a barge and just a little offshore, dump the pieces in a line. In no time nature will use this and coral will grow and lobsters will live in the broken pipes.

Best of all it will protect our beaches, for many years to come, and save money in the process.

John Spatuzzi, Palm City

Recently our country has witnessed a rupture between those who feel that their individual freedom is being violated by local or state orders to stay at home and close businesses, and those who feel that these restrictions, no matter how personally onerous they may be, are necessary for the common good and safety.

Thus we read of armed vigilantes carrying AR-15 semiautomatic rifles surrounding a tattoo parlor in Odessa, Texas, to protect an owner who is defying state orders. We all have seen similarly armed vigilantes storming the state capitol in Lansing, Michigan, to try to intimidate the state governor to make her comply with their interpretation of their constitutional right to go anywhere they want whenever they want.

They are mistaken about their constitutional rights, particularly in an emergency like this pandemic. Nor do they have the right to arm themselves to deliberately intimidate their fellow citizens or their duly-elected officials trying to protect the general public. These are the acts of thugs who represent a minority view but think they can threaten their fellow citizens with guns to get their way.

In a recent letter I read, "Closing beaches here in Florida is like outlawing prayer in church. Not acceptable under any circumstances." Here we have the same total misunderstanding of our individual rights (plus a horrible analogy!). As a retired history teacher, I get depressed reading these comments, about these vigilante actions and wonder what we teachers have failed to do to educate our citizens.

The three examples I mention all indicate a serious problem many Americans have in putting their personal desires over the common good, wishful thinking over science, and opinion over facts. It's time to grow up!

Andrew Sorbo, Sebastian

Now that Gov. Ron DeSantis has lifted the prohibition on elective medical procedures in Florida, it is important for individuals who have been putting off important tests and treatments to see their physicians for the care they need.

While the prohibition was necessary to ensure Florida's healthcare system was capable of handling the COVID-19 crisis, an unintended consequence was that many people with conditions ranging from abdominal pain to trauma stayed home instead of getting the early treatment that could minimize damage and improve patient outcomes.

To prevent a second healthcare crisis, people need to know that physician practices have reopened in every part of the state with protocols in place to ensure that patients are cared for safely.

The Florida Medical Association, along with the American Medical Association and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, have provided guidelines and checklists for physician practices to follow to ensure that patients are protected to the greatest extent possible. Requiring patients to wear face coverings, limiting non-patient visitors, and screening patients before in-person visits are among the new protocols that have been put into place. Testing of physicians and medical staff members has increased and enhanced sanitization procedures have been implemented.

Physician practices are taking these extra precautions to encourage their patients to continue obtaining in-person care when medical attention is needed - especially those with preexisting conditions that require follow-up care with a healthcare provider.

Patients who have chronic medical problems need to have regular check-ups to make sure they are doing well. Postponing care because of the COVID-19 crisis puts patients at high risk for complications later and eventually could cause a treatable condition to become untreatable.

The resulting complications could end up being worse than the (COVID-19) disease.

Ronald Giffler, Tallahassee

Ronald Giffler, M.D., J.D., M.B.A., is President of the Florida Medical Association

Why do delivery people no longer knock when leaving a package at our residences?

In the past they always knocked to alert us that we had a delivery. A good system, I think. In the last few months we had numerous things delivered and the driver did not knock. This includes UPS, Amazon and Walmart, among others.

I asked one driver why he didn't knock and he said it was because he had taken a photo to show that the item arrived at the proper destination. I explained that this in no way protected me from having the item stolen.

Some companies send constant updates as to where your shipment is and when it is delivered at your door. That is all well and good, but is not a reason to not knock on the door of the home when the package is dropped off. I don't sit at my computer all day. Nor am I constantly using a smart phone.

On YouTube you can see a lot of videos of thieves stealing packages from door-steps and porches. They are known as "Porch Pirates." The delivery companies know this is happening. In a couple videos you can see the driver lay the package down, take a photo, and then pick up the item and walk away with it.

Come on, delivery companies, you should and can do better. In the past, I admired drivers because they were so thoughtful. Last week a driver left a package, containing medication, in the sun when two feet away shade was available all day. No, he didn't knock.

Jerry Brewer, Fort Pierce
